title: rewilders-soul-science-says-need-reconnect-nature
story: When, last year, I was working with photographer Anna Deacon, on our book about wild-swimming, Taking The Plunge, one of the things that struck me was how many people said they came to the water because it gave them a connection with nature. They felt a pleasure in being immersed and connected to the le that swum and floated around them. ldquoBeing in the landscape, in nature, is a key thing about swimming in the sea for me, said East Lothian swimmer Lil Vischer, ldquoand itrsquos the one landscape you can get into, right up to your nose. A complete immersion.Our book looked at some of the research into what plunging into chilly water and exposing yourself to sudden cold water shock was doing to us physiologically, and how that might link with its increasingly vaunted physical and mental health benefits. We also touched briefly on how time spent in nature is being shown, in a myriad of ways, to be good for us. In Shetland, GPs have been authorised to give "green prescriptions" such as rambling or bird-watching . As a society we are waking up to the fact that stepping outside and finding some green space, might be not just be enjoyable, but therapeutic. A new book on the subject, by Isabel Hardman, is even catchily titled The Natural Health Service.Next weekend, a clutch of authors who have an interest in the kind of nature-connecting activities are speaking at Aye Write ndash these include Alice Vincent, author of the millennial gardening memoir Rootbound: Rewilding A Le, Lucy Jones, Anna Deacon and myself, as well as Gregory Kenicher, author of Scottish Plant Lore.But connecting to nature doesnrsquot have to involve a long hike in the hills, or plunge in a river ndash it can be done closer to home. Rootbound author Alice Vincentrsquos rewilding has been in urban gardening. ldquoI couldnrsquot leave London. My le was in the city, my support network was there, and I found greater excitement and reassurance in seeing plants thrive in the cracks in the concrete and being able to tend a tiny little plot. Gardening, she says, ldquoslowed me down, offered me a kind of meditation that I couldnrsquot find anywhere  in my le.One person who has looked more deeply than most into this question of the science of why we respond as we do to nature, is Losing Eden author Lucy Jones. Her journey into researching why we feel better when we take a break in some green space, or wander along a beach, or tend a garden, began with her own rewilding. Jones turned to nature, to long walks in Walthamstow Marshes, as her a healing form of rehab following drug and alcohol addiction. She writes, beautully, "Nature picked me up by the scruff of my neck, and I rested in her teeth for a while."The research she discovered on why being in nature is good for us was hugely erse. ldquoMy mind was blown by the iety and depth of the evidence , she says.She delved into studies in the field of biophilia ndash biologist EO Wilsonrsquos term for the idea that we have an innate affinity to other le, and are drawn to living things, and that is an expression of our genes. Jones was interested in why, for instance, we were attracted to certain landscapes, trees, or vistas. ldquoOne of the things that I personally noticed was that there was a sprawling, dark yew tree in the entrance of the cemetery and very time I went under this quite thick, deep canopy, I always felt like I had taken a split-second yoga class.When she looked at studies around tree shape, she found research by Gordon Orians at the University of Washington, that showed we prefer trees that are the same shape as those that would have helped us, by offering shelter and safety, in our evolutionary history. ldquoThese are trees, she says, ldquowith a broad canopy that spreads in width further than its height and it has umbrella-like branches and small leaves.That sense of biophilia is also there in our feelings about open waters. The idea that we have a ldquoblue mind that responds to being near water, was popularised by Wallace Nichols, in his book The Blue Mind: he Surprising Science That Shows How Being Near, In, On, or Under Water Can Make You Happier, Healthier, More Connected, and Better at What You Do. Even looking at images of water relaxes us. Project Soothe, a study at Edinburgh University, has been finding that many of the images we find most relaxing and soothing are those involving water.Jones discovered that MRI scans are showing that looking at fractals, the kind of patterns we find regularly in nature ndash in a tree, a shell, a fern ndash lowers our stress levels. She also looked into the research that had been done into sense of awe ndash that feeling we have when we look at a mountain landscape or the sun setting over the sea. ldquoTherersquos a really exciting new field of the science of awe which has come out of Calornia in the last ten years. Most awe experiences do come through contact with nature. At this laboratory in Berkley Calornia, they studied the effect of awe experiences on an inflammation biomarker in the body, cytokines. They tested for these with ious positive emotions and found that it was only awe that reduced levels of cytokines to a signicant degree. Cytokines, she points out, are associated with disease, depression and ill health. ldquoThat suggested that these awe experiences werenrsquot only giving us a momentary boost of wonder, they were also having a direct influence on our health and le expectancy.A great deal of research in her book covers the importance of trees and green spaces. ldquoWhen I set out on my journey, I instinctively knew that trees are nice and having them on your road is nice in some way. But I didnrsquot expect the strength of the evidence. Studies have found having trees on the street where you live relates to lower levels of anti-depressant use.Tree cover, seeing green, has a measurable impact on public health. It affects mental health, physical health, longevity of le.But not all of us have the same opportunities to connect with green spaces. ldquoTherersquos an inequality of access to nature," says Jones, "and inequality of access to quality of nature as well. People in lower socio-economic groups or from racial and ethnic minorities usually have less access to green space and parks than those who are white and affluent. In towns and cities, there are fewer parks in deprived areas, compared with affluent areas. Yet, good access to green space is something that actually has the potential to help reduce health inequality. One of the experts Jones interviewed was Professor Rich Mitchell of the Social and Public Health Sciences Unit at Glasgow University, who has pioneered the concept of equigenesis ndash the idea that certain environments can reduce the gap between the rich and the poor by weakening the link between socio-economic inequality and health inequality. His studies e have shown that people who lived near parks and woodlands had lower levels of income- related health inequalitiesSuch research suggests that it isnt just important that we rewild ourselves, but that we rewild our cities and societies. We need a wider rewilding revolution. As Jones puts it, "It should be a human right for everybody to have access to the natural world ndash and thatrsquos something wersquore failing at as a society."The authors mentioned in this piece, Vicky Allan, Anna Deacon, Lucy Jones and Alice Vincent, will be speaking at events at Aye Write in Glasgow on March .Everyday ways to rewild your leTake a micro-breakAccording to Lucy Jones, you donrsquot have to go on a long hike in the wilderness to get the benefits of nature. ldquoYou can do it in a micro-break, she says. ldquoStudies have found thatwe take green micro breaks at work ndash looking at a tree, even a pot plant, or out of a window onto a garden, it helped concentration for people who are feeling mentally fatigued.Smell the earth after it has rainedThat aroma is called petrochor, and the compound, Lucy Jones says, it contains is geosmin. ldquoIf yoursquove smelt that itrsquos a beautul smell. Early studies have shown that when people smell that, it activates parts of the brain associated with relaxation and calmness.Get up early and listen to the dawn chorusStudies show that listening birdsong or other natural sounds make a dference to our mental and physical health.Walk to work, or meet friends for an amble rather than a drinkJust taking a walk to work through a tree-lined avenue or a park, can potentially have therapeutic benefit. Lucy Jones says, ldquoIrsquove found that suggesting to a friend to meet up for walks is quite a cool way of incorporating nature in. I donrsquot drink anymore, I try to meet up for walks with friends.

title: joanna-blythman-seems-march-tune-successfully-part
story: And now lets add the Dapper Mongoose, a name Irsquoll recall only long enough to write this review. But its location- Shawlands, Glasgow- and itrsquos cooking- not derivative, surprising- now those nuggets of information I will retain for future reference. And visually, perhaps its blueness: indigo lighting that makes a feature of the bar, those azure blue tiles bathed in turquoise light, and the leggy bar chairs all stop the interior looking humdrum.The menu here wakes up my jaded palate. So often you read a menu once, find nothing much that you fancy, then scrutinise it again, trying to make the best of a bad job. Not here. Actually therersquos competition dishes vie with one another. Fortunately itrsquos a small plates selection, so we are not too conflicted.We dip into a luxuriant chicken liver pateacute, puce pink and stf like thick whipped cream with just an undertone of sweet alcohol. It comes with toasted chunks of creditable sourdough from nearby Deanston bakery and its weight again in lsquotodayrsquos butterrsquo- with Spanish morcillaand crisp bacon beaten into it- which impregnates it with a smoky minerality. Alongside comes sweetly piquant pickled chilli, shallot, carrot, celery, and samphire. This assembly would make a nice lunch on its own, and itrsquos a steal for pound. Meanwhile, three little slow-cooked, golden-crusted beef nuggets strike a pose on their glass plate. Their rich veal jus glimmers as does the liquorice-black pool of sticky-sweet fermented black garlic aioli. Inside this delicate crust the meat comes away in tender shreds.: Zinfandel Gastro Bar, Nithsdale Road, Glasgow. Restaurant review by Ron MackennaAngularly cut caullower, roasted to just the right point where itrsquos definitely cooked, but not mushy, is distinguished from some wannabe Ottolenghi effort by its flavour-loaded smoked cheese velouteacute. A smidgen of date jam, a quivering confit egg yolk also make the brassica more unctuous, while a snowfall of crispy fried onions adds contrasting texture. How good is this lamb rump  Maybe at this time of year it almost qualies as hogget, meat from older, more mature sheep. Certainly its intrinsic flavour is there in force, and itrsquos so pink and dreamily tender. A star in and of itself, the lamb comes with salt-baked beetroot that taste exceptionally of themselves, amber-crusted potatoes- in a sort of pommes Anna treatment, only made with duck fat rather than butter- with smoked whipped feta, and a judicious amount of black olive crumb layering on salty savouriness. A phenomenal plateful for pound, substantial enough to be a main course, and given the high cost of lamb, a definite bargain.lsquoGelrsquo  That words usually worries me, but this pearly cod in its IPA batter that comes with a lemon rendition converts me to the G word itrsquos strikingly right with the deep-fried fish. Heap on this Jalapeno rf on tartare sauce, and celeriac remoulade, Irsquom drooling. This line-up doesnrsquot need its bao bun presentation. I ignore said bun. Parsnips  This treatment is innovative- golden with turmeric and honey, but I search for, and donrsquot find the promised presence of curry leaves.Itrsquos the same with the warm coconut rice pudding, which comes with roasted pineapple carpaccio, and coconut ice cream. What happened to the lsquolychee gelrsquo  So subtle I missed it  And these lsquoCrunchiersquo waffles with near molten honeycomb under them, topped with dark chocolate ganache, honeycomb ice cream, and a honey and lavender sauce, are galumphing. The ganache would make great truffles, the rest is OTT sweet and stodgy, but hearty eaters will doubtless lap them up.Overall though, the Dapper Duck, or whatever this place is called, isnrsquot playing safe in the suburbs. It seems to march to its own tune, successfully, for the most part.The Dapper Mongoose,  Kilmarnock Road, Glasgow   Food:  and a half Service:  Atmosphere:  Value for money:  Joanna BlythmanGuild of Food Writers Food Writer of the Year

title: dundee-havent-visited-yet
story: Once such memorable line: "Ive been to Georgia and Calornia, and anywhere I could run". Before lamenting: "Ive been to paradise. But Ive never been to me."While idly perusing a map the other day, there came a startling realisation: Ive been to Georgia and Calornia. But Ive never been to Dundee.Now, I appreciate thats up there with trying to fathom why on earth the band Genesis would reform. There is no good reason. Not visiting Dundee is like someone saying they have never tried pasta. Or breathing.I should state early doors that Ive nothing against Dundee. Quite the opposite in fact. Making my lack of acquaintance all the more peculiar.: Susan Swarbrick: I didnrsquot choose the West Lothian le, the West Lothian le chose meIm no stranger to exploring our fine nation and its many nooks. Over the years, Ive visited Leuchars, Cupar, Scone, Coupar Angus, Errol ndash each practically within spitting distance of Dundee ndash yet, Dundee itself, a mere  miles up the road from Glasgow where I type this, remains elusive.Given it is known as the City of Discovery, this is an irony that even Alanis Morissette could appreciate. Its assomeone has drawn a big red circle around the boundary. An exclusion zone. Close but no cigar.Not for me the joys of jute and jam . I havent posed for an arty, filtered shot beside the sleek lines of the VA Dundee, an Instagram staple up there with The Kelpies and Skyes Fairy Pools.Nor plonked my backside on the bucket beside the statue of Oor Wullie at The McManus. Theres been no marvelling at Scott and Shackletons famed Antarctic expedition ship or sampling a mixed-origin meat delicacy from Bob Servants Broughty Ferry burger van.Oddly, as a child, I long dreamed about going to Dundee. I would sit at my grans kitchen table, drinking mugs of sweet tea and mainlining KitKats as she recounted spine-tingling stories about major events from history. The one that always captured my imagination was the Tay Bridge disaster.: Susan Swarbrick: I didnrsquot choose the West Lothian le, the West Lothian le chose meMorbid curiosity told me Id like to see that one bridge one day. In the decades since, Ive climbed high on the Sydney Harbour Bridge, sailed beneath New Yorks Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge and driven across the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco with the wind in my hair.Traversing the River Tay has proved a bridge too far. This needs to be rectied post haste.

title: wendy-chamberlain-my-dad-said-eejits-telly-politicians-point
story: Wendy Chamberlain, MP for North East Fe, told The Herald on Sunday of her plans to push for constitutional reforms ahead of the partyrsquos spring conference next week.The MP, who won her seat in the most marginal constituency in the country in the December General Election, said without reforms, the democratic process in the UK risked losing younger voters and those from erse backgrounds.It comes after the electoral reform society said the snap election saw millions of voters ldquototally unrepresented, with % of votes wasted. They analysed the results, determining that it took almost , votes to elect one Green MP, while each SNP MP needed just , and .% of the electorate voted for candidates who did not win.Chamberlain explained: ldquoFirst-past-the-post is the most undemocratic voting system a democracy can have, and we have to look at what opportunities there are to change that.ldquoIt is particularly concerning to see what the Conservatives are planning around voter registration, demanding ID etc. Democracy should be inclusive and enabling, and those measures do neither of those things.ldquoThey are likely to decrease the likelihood of people voting, and when we look at the demographics of people who do vote it tends to be older, less erse groups. It is a vicious cycle in terms of people getting engaged.ldquoThe fact that % of the vote in Scotland delivered % of the seats, it could be argued that reform is more critical in Scotland and it is more evident that it is not working here. The percentage of wasted votes in Scotland is arguably higher.Chamberlain, who is the partys constitutional affairs spokeswoman, will lead on a policy motion at the upcoming conference aimed at fixing "broken politics", with proposals including giving -year-olds the vote, making the House of Lords an elected chamber, and replacing first past the post with a "single transferable vote" system.She said that not only would a change from first-past-the-post be an opportunity to increase ersity among those voting, it would create greater opportunities for ersity among elected politicians too.The MP, whose husband is an SNP member, revealed further political ersity within her own family when she joked: ldquo My dad, he is really a sort of Tory and he likes to put out the Daily Mail just to annoy Keith [my husband] and me.ldquoWhen I got selected he said lsquoWhen I found out you were getting involved in all this politics stuff I thought you were aff yer heid, but then I look at those eejits on the telly and I think you can be just as good as themrsquo.ldquoOn one hand he has got a point hellip is our democracy potentially preventing us from getting more competent people  If the Conservatives or Labour find a safe seat they are kind of sorted. It makes it dficult for smaller parties though to work on their ersity.ldquoThe Conservatives can, and have, put good people from erse backgrounds into seats where they know they will be guaranteed an opportunity to win whereas for ourselves nowhere is a safe sea. One of the things we have got is a good local aspect, but does that prevent us getting a real ersity and breadth of talent The LibDem MP praised the Scottish Governmentrsquos progress on electoral reform and said there were elements of how the proportional representation system works in Scotland which could be applied to the Westminster elections. She has also urged Labourrsquos leadership and deputy leadership candidates to get behind the proposals for change.She said: ldquoI am supportive of what the Scottish government have done, with giving votes to -year-olds and having EU citizens included. There is a degree of cross-party consensus on some aspects too.ldquoWe have written to all Labour the candidates, Keir Starmer has made noises and now hersquos talking about a consultation. Ian Murray says he is the lsquochangersquo candidate so where are you on first past the post, Ian  Labour are facing a potentially devastating performance down south in council elections. Its actually in their interest, itrsquos in the whole countryrsquos interest, to change the system.The Government has proposed ious changes system over the past year, none of which involves moving away from first-past-the-post. Critics have argued that proposals to introduce mandatory presentation of photo-ID at polling stations would simply rule out many voters, and reducing the number of constituencies to  from  would bring together areas with little in common.

title: Rosemary Goring  39 s Country Life  the heated question of     heat
story: Here in the heart of the Borders, I look back on that flat with nostalgia. Aside from the occasional draught which we could dodge by retreating to the back room, it was wonderfully toasty. This was in large part thanks to generous neighbours above and below whose central heating kept us permanently cocooned.In the country, as I quickly learned, in winter there are two main subjects of conversation: weather and warmth, but the greater of these is warmth. Hoolet, like many villages around here, has no gas supply, so central heating runs either by electricity or oil. The topic of electricity bills leads to much sucking in of breath, although there was one couple whose house somehow escaped the notice of the electricity board.Only when they sold up and the new owners found they werenrsquot being charged did it become clear why there had always been such a blazing array of Christmas lights in this particular garden. Rumour has it that, years earlier, a woman in this area greased a palm and had her meter erted to a lamp-post. It took a while before the extraordinarily high reading was finally noticed and an investigation began. Soon she was tracked down, along with her cannabis plants.The day is approaching when wersquoll all have to switch to renewables, but in the meantime our radiators drink oil. Every few days I check the gauge on the tank in the garden, half-closing my eyes as I pull out the pin and watch it drop one inch, then two. Since it can take over a week between ordering and getting a refill, you have to estimate how long it will last. If nothing , becoming aware of every drop of oil you use does mean that, while itrsquos the least environmentally friendly of fuels, it is never squandered. One friend is so thrty her grandchildren have renamed her house The Baltic.Long before, and after, they became fashionable, everyone around here wears a gilet. People only come to their doors in a tee-shirttheyrsquove been interrupted in the process of layering. I was watching a western the other night and saw a tobacco-spitting rancher on his porch, rle under his stained armpit. What caught my attention was his long-johns, the sort that reach from ankle to chin to wrist, with buttons down the front. Theyrsquore exactly what I need.Other than the relief of seeing the orange lights of the oil tanker arriving in the pitch black of a winterrsquos morning, there is nothing interesting about oil. Our other source of heat, however, is wood-burning stoves, and on this subject I could win Mastermind. We have two, which possibly saved my husbandrsquos le. When the Beast From the East descended on Hoolet, he was left with a gaping hole in the kitchen wall where the boiler had been taken out moments before the blizzard started. The heating engineers fled to get over Soutra Hill before they were snowed in, and his ordeal began: two log fires and two hot water bottles to get him through five days until the roads reopened. When he went into the kitchen to cook dinner, he had to wear hat and gloves as well as his puffa jacket.There is nothing more comforting in the cold than a roaring fire. In rural parts this is not a lestyle choice but an absolute necessity. Of an evening we get through about five logs, which is enough to keep a large room really cosy. When we started out, we were so ignorant wersquod never even heard the phrase ldquokiln dried and ndash Irsquom going beetroot just thinking about it ndash we bought logs in bags from BQ. Now, having found a good supplier, and with our own woodstore, the first thing we notice as we drive around the area is other peoplersquos woodpiles.Some are works of art, high as a gable end and stacked so expertly theyrsquore as solid as drystane dykes. A few keep them in a ramshackle heap, out in the open, where they soak up the rain. Quite apart from the level of emissions wet wood produces, which is why itrsquos high on the governmentrsquos hit-list, it is far less efficient, generating less warmth and more smoke. Butyoursquore patient, green wood dries out ndash Irsquove heard you should wait two years for anything yoursquove cut down yourself. My father would have scoffed at that, as hersquod bring the car to a sudden halt, nip out and drag a huge storm-tossed branch into the boot ndash ldquotidying up the countryside as he put it. Back home, he stoked the flames so high we had to push the furniture back against the walls and open the living room door.The other day we had a delivery of ash, dumped in front of the house in a crate big enough to hold a wild boar. As the lumberjack was in bed barking like a sea-lion, it fell to me to deal with it. I was well on my way when Lazarus rose from the duvet to check on the proceedings and pointed out that I was laying them sideways rather than end-on. As the sun disappeared and clouds gathered I started again. By this time a neighbour had spotted me, and helped me finish the job.The sense of satisfaction in having it all safely stored, shortly before snowfall, was incalculable. Thatrsquos the thing about wood. The connection between you and the trees yoursquore burning creates a new respect and understanding. For a start, freshly chopped logs give off a delicious scent. And each one is dferent ndash whorled, fissured, misshapen, or neatly wedged like a giant slice of cake. If you chose to count the rings yoursquod see how many years had gone into making a blaze that lasts only a few hours.

title: world-womens-day-comment-equality-issue-us-not-just-women
story: This International Womenrsquos Day is on the theme ldquoEach for Equal, recognising that all of us have a role to play to bring about the gender equality we seek both in Scotland and around the world.A quarter of a century ago in Beijing, world leaders agreed a Declaration and Platform for Action on equality, development and peace for women. It was subsequently signed by  governments, yet progress since then has been uneven.Inequalities between women and men continue ndash most notably in the ongoing equal pay debate, but as seen also in the under-representation of women in senior positions in business, the public sector, our parliaments and local councils.Women and girls around the world still face hardship, poverty, violence and inequality.Here in Scotland there is a lot to be proud of. We are taking action to challenge gender stereotypes in early learning and education and tackle all forms of violence against women and girls, and we have committed to developing a womenrsquos health plan. And we are leading the world through the provision of free period products in education and community settings, reaching now more than half a million people.The workplace is one of the most challenging areas where discrimination and inequality remains. Its  years since the passage of the Equal Pay Act, but the average gender pay gap for employees in Scotland is  per cent. While this is three per cent lower than the rest of the UK, and the gap has narrowed over the past decade, itrsquos clear there is more to do and we are tackling this through our Gender Pay Gap Action Plan.Our STEM strategy includes measures ndash beginning in the early years ndash to tackle inequality and stereotypes which put girls off studying subjects such as maths, engineering and the sciences. Just last month, the Deputy First Minister chaired the first meeting of a Gender Equality Taskforce in Education.The role played by women in rural industries such as farming is often downplayed or undervalued, and in response to the recommendations of our Women in Agriculture Taskforce, we are providing support and training to help women take up leadership roles and other opportunities.Of course equal pay and equality across workplaces are just part of the jigsaw. Women still assume the majority of caring responsibilities in households.Which is why our transformation of childcare provision to double the number of free hours is so vital. It is happening in combination with other efforts to improve parental employment support for those on low incomes and to encourage better practice for parental leave ndash though this area remains reserved to the UK Government.The Scottish Government has introduced legislation to improve access to forensic medical services for victims of sexual offences. And we have strengthened the law on domestic abuse, to give women better protection against all forms of abuse and controlling behaviour.Funding for frontline services to support women and children has increased to pound million in - to deliver on the Equally Safe strategy ndash reflecting the fact that until women feel safe, they will not be equal.Three years ago the First Minister established the National Advisory Council on Women and Girls, and their second report recommendations focused on how we can shape better policies for women and girls across Scotland, and how we make sure that their voices are heard. This sends the message loud and clear that equality policy is not just one personrsquos job, itrsquos everyonersquos job ndash encapsulating this yearrsquos theme of being Each for Equal.I am proud of what we are doing across all areas of government to help realise gender equality in Scotland.And it is work we should all support ndash because, as Hillary Clinton famously declared in Beijing, "womenrsquos rights are human rights" and womenrsquos equality is good for all of humanity.bull Shirley-Anne Somerville is Cabinet Secretary for Social Security and Older People

title: taylor-swift-making-ukulele-cool
story: IT was immortalised by a music hall entertainer as he leaned against a lamppost at the corner of his street.Now the ukulele is enjoying a resurgence in popularity as stars such as Taylor Swt bring it to a modern audience far removed from the days of George Formby.Multi-Grammy award-winner Swt will pack her ukulele for a tour of European festivals this summer, including a headline slot at Glastonbury.The -year-old starrsquos fondness for the humble, four-string instrument ndash dismissed harshly in some quarters as nothing more than an irritating toy ndash is reckoned to be one of the reasons more and more people are learning to play it.ldquoTaylor Swt is a star so she has definitely influenced a lot of young people who are now playing the ukulele, and that is so pleasing, said Glasgow-based Finlay Allison, one of the pre-eminent ukulele tutors in the country.ldquoShe has shown that it is cool to play the ukulele which, undoubtedly, boosts the instrumentrsquos appeal to younger people. But itrsquos obvious that middle-age and older folk are showing greater interest than ever before as well.Alison, a key member of the Glasgow Folk-Music Workshop, led a highly successful, two-day ukulele school during Celtic Connections in January that attracted more than  players.One of the great charms of the ukulele, he says, is someone can be playing a tune on it after one lesson, eventhat person has never played any instrument before.There are fewer strings on a ukulele ndash four ndash so this simplies the learning process.ldquoWith instruments such as the French horn, oboe, violin or piano, learners have a long spell in the foothills before they can play a tune, but with the ukulele itrsquos dferent, Alison said.ldquoYou can get on to the big ridge to play much more quickly with the ukulele, and this is one of the things that inspires people of all ages to pick one up ... and a player gets instant feedback with the sweet sounds that emerge. Another good thing about the ukulele is itrsquos easy to carry around and that appeals to people. Therersquos no hassle.In the th century, the ukulele appeared in Hawaii having been adapted from a small, guitar-like instrument known as a machete that Portuguese immigrants took to the island.Four main types of ukulele are currently played ndash soprano , concert, tenor and baritone.Today in the UK there have never been so many ukulele clubs ndash more than , according to the Ukulele Society Of Great Britain, which was formed in .Its secretary, James Spencer, pointed out the huge social benefits they can bring.ldquoThere are a number of reasons for the rising popularity of ukulele clubs, but one is it gets people out of the house, said Spencer, who started playing the ukulele just over five years ago.ldquoThe clubs help create a social network and I think the more people who hear the ukulele played, the more they want to join in and play it themselves.ldquoOur club members play in clubs and nursing homes and so on, and everyone enjoys their visits.The society holds two conventions in Hertfordshire each year ndash in April and October ndash but festivals are planned in other parts of the country.In the United States, too, the ukulele is riding a new wave of popularity and already this year there has been a festival in Indiana, and a two-day gathering is taking place in Maryland this month.Blair Jackson, editor of Ukulele Magazine in the States, said: ldquoThere are ever-growing legions of folks ndash young and old ndash who have taken up the instrument more recently.ldquoThe ukulele has never been a more international instrument than it is today, with new clubs springing up all the time.ldquoThe ranks of established ones are still growing and more uke-focused events are popping up around the globe.The late George Harrison, the quiet Beatle, was a huge ukulele fan.ldquoEverybody should have and play a uke, said Harrison. ldquoItrsquos so simple to carry with you and it is one instrument you canrsquot play and not laugh ... I love them ndash the more the merrier.Harrison also gted a uke to his fellow Traveling Wilbury, American singer songwriter, the late Tom Petty, but he said he already had one. ldquoYou can never have enough ukuleles, Harrison responded.Screen icon Marilyn Monroe famously played the ukulele in the classic film Some Like It Hot alongside Tony Curtis and Jack LemonAmerican guitarist, the late Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead, also enjoyed playing it while Eddie Vedder, frontman of stadium rockers Pearl Jam, stunned many in  when he won a Grammy nomination in the Best Folk Album category for his Ukulele Songs release.Another George ndash Englishman George Formby, who died in  ndash was a vaudeville entertainer who is credited with greatly increasing the ukulelersquos popularity in the s and s.The Ukulele Orchestra Of Great Britain ndash hailed by the late David Bowie as ldquowonderfully clever ndash heads off for a -date tour of the USA and Canada this month, promising audiences ldquoa funny, virtuosic, twanging, awesome, foot-stomping show.At the end of May it is due to play at The Queenrsquos Hall in Edinburgh.Its members say they are all-singing, all-strumming ukulele players with instruments bought with ldquoloose change. Their belief is that all genres of music are ldquoavailable for reinterpretation, as long as they are played on the ukulele.From Tchaikovsky to Nirvana via Queen, Otis Redding and Spaghetti Western soundtracks, the orchestra likes to offer listeners ldquoone plucking thing after another.As it says on its Facebook page: ldquoYou may never think about music in the same way once yoursquove been exposed to the ukesrsquo depraved musicology.One Scottish musician who has been distinctly unimpressed with the instrument is school music tutor Davy Lees, who works for Fe Youth Music Initiative and also broadcasts for Glasgow-based charity station, Celtic Music Radio.He prefers the guitar for teaching and performing but last month he picked up the ukulele for the first time and learned to play the folk song Freight Train after a friend threw down a challenge.ldquoIrsquom glad I did it and the ukulele I learned to play was a nice wee instrument, but Irsquom going to stick with the guitar, said Lees.However, his brief dalliance with the uke paid off as it helped him raise more than pound for Strathcarron Hospice.Prices for ukuleles start at around pound, though the worldrsquos most expensive, made by John DrsquoAngelico in , sold on eBay in  for ,.ldquoIt is safe to say that the ukulele is no longer considered uncool, said Finlay Allison. ldquoThese days it is clearly on the up and up and thatrsquos great.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Alex Salmond     the trial that could split the SNP from top to bottom
story: Tomorrow, in Edinburghrsquos High Court, Alex Salmond, the former SNP leader and First Minister of Scotland, will go on trial accused of  criminal charges including attempted rape, sexual assault and harassment.Journalists ndash and the political world ndash have been talking of little  for months.It would, of course, be illegal to report any rumours or the identity of the claimants. The accusers in sexual assault and rape trials have anonymity.Journalists or editors who disclose any information that could prejudice a criminal trial, or make comments likely to influence jurors, could be guilty of contempt of court, and end up in jail.Already, one pro-SNP commentator, the former British diplomat Craig Murray, has been warned by the Crown Office that a satirical post he published in January could be ldquogravely in contempt.So, no satire or speculation from me. I make no comment about Mr Salmondrsquos guilt or innocence. Irsquoll just say that these are serious charges, potentially carrying long prison sentences.And that the Crown Office has released a lot of detail already.The indictment alleges that Mr Salmond attempted to rape a woman in his official residence in Bute House in June . He is said to have pinned her against a wall, to have removed her clothes and his own, before pushing her on to a bed and lying naked on top of her.In December , he is alleged to have caused a woman to lie on his bed, struggled with her and pulled up her dress.Other charges include an allegation he groped a woman in the Ego nightclub in Edinburgh in or around , and to have removed a womanrsquos shoe in  and tried to kiss her foot.Mr Salmond insists that he is innocent of all criminal charges.Like any defendant, the former First Minister has the presumption of innocence on his side. His guilt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt.This trial ndash of one of the leading Scottish politicians of the age ndash will have huge political reverberations. It comes at a crucial moment for the SNP and the nationalist movement.Salmondrsquos prosecution intersects with growing isions over the future direction of the independence campaign. It could also affect Nicolarsquos Surgeonrsquos future as leader.There is a parliamentary inquiry into what the First Minister knew about the allegations about her mentor, and when she knew them. She has admitted that she held a number of private meetings with Salmond about the allegations without informing her civil servants.More seriously, this trial breaks just as increasing numbers of SNP activists are despairing of the prospects for a second independence referendum. Sturgeon keeps promising to deliver indyref, but it never arrives.Many frustrated nationalists believe thatAlex Salmond had still been leading the party, there would have been a referendum of some sort by now. They believe Sturgeon is too small lsquocrsquo conservative. Too insistent on a strictly legal route to independence.Salmond ndash and I state this not as a character reference ndash was one of the most successful populist politicians Britain has ever produced. An insurgent with a unique gt for communicating with Scottish voters of all backgrounds, he always led from the front.In , after he became leader of the SNP, he pulled the party to the left and made ldquoIndependence in Europe the partyrsquos mission statement. Then, in the mid-s, he defeated the fundamentalists in the party and persuaded the SNP to support devolution.Labour Politicians like the Cabinet minister, George Robertson, said that the Scottish Parliament, inaugurated in , would ldquokill nationalism stone dead. It did precisely the reverse.In , Alex Salmond declared himself First Minister of the first SNP Government in history. Then,in , he led the SNP to a landslide election victory and demanded a referendum on independence.At the time, independence was much less popular than the SNP. This was why the then-prime minister, David Cameron, agreed to a referendum in the first place thinking he couldnrsquot lose. In the event, the Yes campaign came within % of winning the  referendum, plunging the UK state into panic.With that track record, it is hardly surprising that many nationalists see Salmond as a politicianwho can literally do no wrong and refuse to believe the charges against him.Two years ago, before the sexual misconduct allegations first arose, Salmond had been making clear he intended toto active politics, following his retirement in . He even suggested he would be one of the leaders of the next independence referendum campaign. Not everyone in the party thought this would be a good thing.At no time did he challenge Nicola Sturgeonrsquos leadership ndash she was, after all, his protege and worked intimately with him for over a decade in the Scottish Government. But Salmond was known to be looking for a safe route back into Parliament.Then in August of that year a story was leaked to the Daily Record that two civil servants had made complaints of sexual misconduct by Alex Salmond in . Salmond rejected the allegations and in turn accused the head of the Scottish Civil Service, Lesley Evans, of misconduct.He took the Scottish Government to the Court of Session and won in January . The Scottish Government admitted fault and ended up paying Alex Salmond pound, of taxpayersrsquo money. It was massive humiliation.Most people, Salmond included, thought that would be an end of the matter. But only weeks later he was arrested by police on multiple charges of attempted rape and sexual assault.His followers simply refuse to believe that this icon of independence is anything but innocent. SNP members have poured tens of thousands into his defence fund.This has allowed him to put together a high-powered defence team, led by Gordon Jackson QC, Dean of the Faculty of Advocates. He is supported by Shelagh McCall QC, the chair of the human rights organisation Justice Scotland.Some years ago, Jackson successfully defended a Collie dog, who was about to be put down after allegedly biting a policeman. He won after Brigitte Bardot flew in to support the defence.Such glamorous witnesses are not expected in the Salmond case. But all eyes will be on the High Court of Justiciary tomorrow to seeJackson can deliver an even greater legal victory.

title: coronavirus-can-panic-yet
story: We are truly in a new age of panic sparked off by the threat of a new virus we donrsquot understand, but which so far has an extremely low mortality rate ndash or, as the US Surgeon General put it, in marked contrast to British medical experts, you are , times more likely to die from flu than coronavirus.But when every news bulletin leads on the latest twist, with the latest count of the diagnosed, film of cruise ships with sufferers moored offshore, sporting events played behind closed doors, no kissing or touching, the Queen in gloves, when the advice is to just wash your hands ndash when such dramatic events warrant an equally dramatic response ndash it seems utterly inadequate. We panic because it feels like wersquore doing something, or evenwersquore not it feels like we should be.One response is to panic buy. People are setting up ldquopandemic pantries to stockpile goods. Australia has all but run out of toilet rolls to the extent that one newspaper printed several blank pages so that buyers could use them in an emergency, which seemed more like a successful PR stunt than a solution. One clip from a Tesco store in Aberdeen showed racks normally filled with hand gels and sanitisers completely empty. When the media runs these stories about panic buying it exacerbates panic buying ndash a shelf-fulfilling prophecy, you could say.In the Second World War there were few media outlets. Social media was something you scrawled on a gable end or in a close mouth, and those that existed were tightly censored, so that every setback, barely reported, was trumpeted as a new beginning. For newspapers, like any incontinent Aussie today, paper was rationed so the news was thin. Nowadays any crackpot computer jockey or scaremonger can trigger a digital snowball effect. In , when some KFC restaurants ran out of chicken in Britain, people were even phoning the police, and probably the Samaritans for all we know.Hysteria needs an audience, evenitrsquos only others staring at screens somewhere in cyberspace. Panic is a bit like laughing in an empty room ndash it makes one feel a little foolish ndash whereas battering out crazed messages on a keyboard seems almost therapeutic.Graham Greene said that writing, like composing a painting, was a kind of therapy ndash an escape from panic and fear. Ralph Waldo Emerson described panic as the terror of ignorance surrendered to the imagination, which is about as a cogent a summation as you can get. So that when experts are at odds over coronavirus, as is understandable when itrsquos such a new one, their ignorance feeds the fear and frees the dark wings of imagination. I said that.There have been panics, most of them unnecessary, since the earliest humans, from which fig leaf to wear to heart flutterings over whether that dinosaur really was a vegetarian . When the Black Death struck it would have taken weeks for the news to filter to the far reaches of the country, probably a lot slower than the disease got there.The most newsworthy, because of the society we live in, have been the panics engendered by economic jolts and crashes, like the Great Depression of  or the global financial crisis of  , although these didnrsquot affect most people.Even last week one US financial commentator was arguing that everyone should be deliberately infected with coronavirus to get it over with quickly, so that the markets would recover ... never mind the thousands or millions who perished.Predictions about the end of the world ndash and there have been thousands ndash did not evoke the level of fear this virus does, probably because so few people heard about it at the time and for each wrong one the next was taken less seriously.Nostradamus put the end of the world at July , Rasputinpinned it more precisely to August , . Jehovahrsquos Witnesses keep getting it wrong ndash  was their last shot.The recent viruses, like Sars, Ebola and Zika, didnrsquot take such hold on the imagination probably, and sadly, because they were overwhelmingly infecting other people in other countries. The HIV Aids one, properly identied in , caused a spike of unease but did not cause wholesale fear outside the gay community ndash largely widespread support and sympathy ndash because once the nation got over the you-can-catch-it-by-kissing-or-shaking-hands thing, there was a clear and avoidable cause.Nonetheless, there was a massive publicity campaign, in the way there hasnrsquot yet been for the coronavirus, featuring doom-laden voices and tumbling tombstones. Perhaps thatrsquos to come.Remember the YK problem, the millennium bug, which was going to crash all computers and programs, cause aircraft to drop from the sky, trigger famine and pestilence, unleash ICBMs from their silos and generally cause a spot of global mischief  Well, not only did it not happen, it passed with a yawn.In , a food scare in Aberdeen, supposedly by contaminated corned beef causing a typhoid outbreak, caused as panic ripple. The Medical Officer of Health, Ian MacQueen, even claimed ndash wrongly ndash through the media that the outbreak was caused by tinned meat from a stockpile the Government kept in case of nuclear war. You donrsquot see much corned beef being sold nowadays so the stigma maybe stuck.Edwina Currie did the same for eggs in , declaring that most carried salmonella . It took  years for the poultry industry to recover.In , the foot-and-mouth outbreak only stopped after over six million cows and sheep were slaughtered. Tourism dropped by around % and it took the European Court of Justice to force France to eventually restock British beef.Panics past, what of the present  Judging by the emptying shelves itrsquos on a new and higher level, out of reach of reality. By comparison, the massive death toll from flu and associated illnesses in the winter of  was more than , but I donrsquot recall similar hysteria. In Scotland, the winter death toll in   was over ,, the overwhelming causes being flu and pneumonia. Neither provoked the fear of this one.Is it justied  Too early to say. The coronavirus appears to be less deadly than Sars, which killed around % of people who became infected, as against about % so far. Because the latest outbreak is still unfolding globally, scientists donrsquot yet definitively know the virusrsquo true fatality rate.However, it has killed nearly three times as many people in eight weeks as Sars did in eight months. There are now more than , people infected across the world, with  in Scotland as The Herald on Sunday went to press.Itrsquos in our nature to worry, andthe -hour news, and fake news, media are doing a great job in playing it up. There are moments totally free from worry. We call these panic.

title: june-almeida-tribute-scotlands-forgotten-hero-coronavirus
story: But the daughter of a Glasgow bus driver is still playing a major role in the fight against coronavirus, nearly  years after her death.For June Almeida, the virologist who discovered the first human coronavirus, has been hailed as "one of the greatest scientists of her generation".Professor Hugh Pennington, emeritus professor of bacteriology at Aberdeen University ndash and one of the countrys leading microbiologists ndash said Mrs Almeida became his mentor.The scientist worked at St Thomas Hospital, London, with Mrs Almeida ndash who he said was "unconventional but brilliant.""Without her pioneering work things would be slower in dealing with the current coronavirus outbreak. Her work has speeded up our understanding of the virus. She was a pioneer," said Prof Pennington."She was an outstanding talent ndash hall of fame, definitely. What she touched in her research turned to gold."Without doubt she is one of the outstanding Scottish scientists of her generation, but sadly largely forgotten. Though ironically this Covid- outbreak has shone a light again on her work."Her work is now helping in the fight against Covid-."For instance the Chinese used her technology to identy it. They repeated what she had done in looking at the culture."What June did is so relevant now. Her methods are still being used and it is helping in the current outbreak."Mrs Almeida, who died in December  aged , had far from a classic scientic path.Incredibly despite little formal education, she became a Doctor of Science and a pioneer in virus imaging, identication and diagnosis.Born at  Duntroon Street, Glasgow, to Jane Dalziel and Harry Leonard Hart, a bus driver, she left school at  to work as a histopathology technician at Glasgow Royal Infirmary.She then moved to St Bartholomews Hospital in London to continue her career.In  she married Enriques RosalioAlmeida, a Venezuelan artist. They had a daughter, Joyce.The family moved to Canada where Mrs Almeida worked at the Ontario Cancer Institute as an electronmicroscopist.Despite having few qualications, she was promoted in line with her outstanding abilities.Publications credited her for her work on identying viral structure. Her talents were recognised by A. P. Waterson, then professor of microbiology at St Thomass Hospital Medical School in London, who persuaded her toto England to work at the hospital.Mrs Almeida developed a method to better visualise viruses by using antibodies to aggregate them. She worked on hepatitis B and the cold virus.She also produced the first images of the rubella virus using immune electron microscopy.And, working with David Tyrrell, she characterised a new type of viruses now called coronaviruses. This family includes the Sars virus."Around  percent of common colds are thought to be caused by the coronavirus they discovered," said Prof Pennington."She discovered the virus that is parent,you like, in this family."Her story is remarkable ndash she left school with hardly any qualications at ."She was feisty without being domineering and had very strong views on science. Firm views strongly held."I never thought being a woman held her back. She was not discriminated against in biology. She made her own way and responded vigorously to any criticism. She was usually right."Her first paper on coronavirus was turned down. It was not well received because it was based on electromicroscopic pictures. But eventually it was published."In fact she was so good she was head-hunted to come back to the UK."What she was good at ndash doing the technology ndash is applied today. She was a pioneer in that particularly. She also had a talent for picking the right topic to work on and not wasting time on things that could not be solved."June was unconventional for a scientist ndash in retirement she became an antique dealer and a yoga teacher. She was a person of many talents."Mrs Almeida followed Prof Waterson to the Postgraduate Medical School in London where her contributions to articles were recognised by her award of a doctorate. She finished her career at the Wellcome Institute.While working for Wellcome she was named on several patents in the field of imaging viruses.After leaving Wellcome ndash and becoming a yoga teacher ndash she was lured back but in an advisory role in the late s when she helped take novel pictures of the HIV virus.She published a World Health Organisation manual for rapid laboratory viral diagnosis in .Never has that been more needed than now.

title: plan-msp-background-checks-voted-next-week
story: The Scottish Liberal Democrats want to bring in new rules requiring all MSPs, MPs and councillors to undergo a Protecting Vulnerable Groupscheck, in a bid to safeguard against exploitative or predatory behaviour.The move comes after Derek Mackay resigned as Finance Secretary following revelations he bombarded a -year-old boy with online messages, including calling him ldquocute.The PVG scheme currently covers those who work with children and protected adults, such as teaching or medical roles. When someone applies to join it, Disclosure Scotland carries out criminal record checks and shares the results with iniduals and organisations.LibDem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton, pictured above, has now lodged a series of amendments to the DisclosureBill to make it an offence for an elected representative to take part in regulated activities without being a member of the scheme. These activities include meeting alone with children and vulnerable adults or spending time unsupervised with young people on work experience.The amendments will be voted on at Holyroodrsquos Education Committee on Wednesday.Cole-Hamilton said his proposal was a ldquocommonsense safety move. He added: ldquoI hope that when this comes to a vote every party in the Parliament will acknowledge the importance of strengthening the protections in place and back my amendments.New rules will set out actionssomeone fails the post-election PVG check, for example potentially requiring MSPs to be chaperoned by someone in possession of a PVG when meeting children or vulnerable adults. The amendments could also see political parties require PVG checks for anyone in a position of power or influence and could spend time unsupervised with children or vulnerable adults, such as target seat candidates or office-bearers.The LibDems said a PVG costs in the region of pound, and the extra expense could be met by the elected institution. Some councils already ask members to undergo such background checks, while others require it of those who sit on children and families committees.The PVG scheme is private, and the public and media would not knowsomeone had failed a check. However, the LibDems argued they would at least know safeguards are in place.The party said the proposal would see MSPs and others undergo a PVG check straight after being elected. This would be renewed every five years, coinciding with both the provisions that exist for other types of work where and theof a typical elected term.MSPs are currently specically excluded from the provisions in the DisclosureBill.But Maree Todd, Minister for Children and Young People, previously said she was ldquomore than happy to assess whether parliamentarians fall within the category of those who should be covered by the scheme.A Scottish Government spokesperson said any proposition ldquomust command wide acceptance across the Parliament and the public. ldquoThese particular amendments have not been consulted upon nor has detailed evidence-based parliamentary scrutiny taken place. While well-intentioned, they present a number of challenges which will have very signicant constitutional implications, not least potentially allowing the removal of MSPs on the instruction of ministers. That would not be acceptable to anyone. As a result, we welcome the debate but are concerned that these specic amendments are not the solution.ldquoThe Scottish Government is, however, keen to see Parliament find an appropriate way forward on this issue in due course.

title: analysis-mixed-messages-scottish-government-doctors-pension-rules
story: Just last month health secretary Jeane Freeman wrote to then-Chancellor Sajid Javid urging him to act.ldquoIt is incumbent upon you to take the opportunity of the March Budget to fully and finally remedy the situation and allow our NHS staff to get on with delivering care without fear of the consequences, she said.What she and the Government have never said, though, is what they would like the Chancellor to do. While politicians like former East Renfrewshire MP Paul Masterton ndash a Conservative member who was a pensions lawyer before entering Parliament ndash called repeatedly for the tapered annual allowance to be scrapped, the Scottish Government has said only that a solution has to be found.One potential reason for the Scottish Governmentrsquos reticence to name the most obvious solution to a problem that is entirely of Westminsterrsquos making is that scrapping the taper would work in First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos favour.Though, like all MSPs, Ms Sturgeonrsquos salary remains frozen at - levels, at pound, it is still well above the pound, threshold at which the taper kicks in, meaning the tax-free amount she can save into her pension will have reduced from pound, a year to just over pound,. As the Government contributes .% of membersrsquo salary to the Scottish Parliamentary Pension Scheme and members contribute either % or %, when pensions growth is factored in Ms Sturgeonrsquos annual contributions will far exceed that limit. She will undoubtedly be liable for annual allowance charges.Figures released by the Scottish Public Pensions Agency under Freedom of Information legislation show that two members of the parliamentary scheme paid an annual allowance charge in each of the two years after the legislation was introduced, with the scheme paying pound, and pound, on membersrsquo behalf in   and   respectively.If the taper or the annual allowance were scrapped, such charges would either be less likely or would no longer be incurred.The Scottish Government did not respond when askedthis was the reason it has not been lobbying for the change senior doctors say is required to keep them in post. It did, however, continue to frame the problem as an NHS-specic one rather than something that is affecting the public sector as a whole.ldquoA permanent solution is only within the gt of the Chancellor, a spokesperson said. ldquoWe have been consistently clear with this Chancellor and his predecessor that he must use the UK Budget on th March to offer this and that this is all the more pressing in light of the current Covid- challenge we all face.

title: herald-voices-truth-reading
story: Recently our sister paper, The Herald, reported that a National Literary Trust Survey found ldquojust a quarter of children read for pleasure every day and that ldquoScottish pupils have the joint greatest level of reading comprehension in UK.So far, so good.However, the picture faded with the news that, ldquoon average, they are reading the least dficult books. Apparently, Harry Potter ldquodominates favourite books, taking the top seven places for primary schools, and is first choice for secondary pupils. What to make of it Well, ldquofor pleasure and ldquoleast dficult leaped from the page for me. The first notion seems purely al, addressing ldquopurpose the second, rhetorical, addressing ldquoquality.On the one hand, Harper Lee, of ldquoMockingbird fame, found that she never loved to read hellip until she feared she would lose the wherewithal so to do. ldquoOne does not love breathing, she reasoned. Yet, literary realism exponent, Gustave Flaubert, felt that we should ldquonot read hellip to amuse ourselves or for the purpose of instruction. No, read in order to live.Regarding ldquodficult  JD Salinger, author of The Catcher in the Rye, admitted he was so ldquoknocked out by certain books, he wished the author was ldquoa terric friend he could phone ldquowhenever he felt like it.However, in our digital world where the lowest common denominator is evermore common, we mere mortals of lesser literary erudition, perhaps, may have our say and try to describe the attraction of reading to us.For example, the aforementioned digital age is put firmly in its place by Groucho Marx: ldquoI find TV very educating. Every time somebody turns on the set, I go into another room and read a book.Daniel Handler, aka Lemony Snicket, goes further: ldquoNever trust anyone who has not brought a book with them. What dinner parties he must throw!Me  Irsquom with Carnegie Medal winner, Neil Gaiman: ldquoStories may well be lies, but they are good lies that say true thingsYou

title: us-elections-last-man-standing
story: All of a sudden itrsquos turned into the Bernie and Joe show. With one-time frontrunner Elizabeth Warren ending her campaign last Thursday, the US Democratic presidential field is now pretty much inhabited by a two-man race between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders for the partyrsquos nomination.Sure, Tulsi Gabbard the congresswoman from Hawaii and her one earned delegate remains in the race , but this is a far cry from the six Democratic women, three African Americans, a Latino, a gay man, and three Asian Americans who stepped up to contend for president earlier this year.Once again white and male seems to be the order of the day when it comes to running for Americarsquos highest office. So just why did things end up this way and what does it tell us about American politics right now as the race for the White House heats up As the New York Times reporter Lisa Lerer pointed out a few days ago, ever since Donald Trump won the presidency womenrsquos rage has fuelled the Democratic Party.In response to Trumprsquos flagrant misogynism, new political organisations sprung up, women led protests like the #MeToo movement, ran for office and voted for Democrats more than they ever had before. There was in effect a fundamental sht in the way many Americans viewed elected power and government.This yearrsquos democratic primary certainly reflected that with a record number of women vying for the chance to run for the US presidency.Of the  main Democratic candidates six were women, including four senators - Elizabeth Warren, Amy Klobuchar, Kamala Harris and Kirsten Gillibrand - along with Tulsi Gabbard, the Hawaii congresswoman, and Marianne Williamson, a motivational speaker.It was back in , when Hillary Rodham Clinton first announced, ldquoIm in, and Im in to win, stoking hope in those Americans who valued political parity and that a woman could become the president of the United States.The talented sorority who stepped up to the challenge this year felt exactly the same way as Clinton, and between them brought together a pool of backgrounds and abilities that included former prosecutors, senators, a combat veteran and a self-help celebrity.Their rise too came off the back of the success of female Democratic candidates in the  midterms, when female voters played a critical role in electing a record-breaking number of women to Congress.On the face of it, things appeared to have come a long way and were turning out for the better. The last time Democrats selected a woman, as the vice-presidential nominee was when Geraldine Ferraro ran as Walter Mondalersquos running mate in , though they lost  of the  states to Ronald Reagan.On the Republican side, the last female vice-presidential candidate was Sarah Palin, whose presence on the ticket was believed to have hurt John McCainrsquos campaign. Some political observers insist though that the lingering legacy of such experiences remains a major hurdle for women contesting for senior office.ldquoSome of the gender dynamics is more like once bitten, twice-shy and unfortunately that dynamic tends to impact women far too often in politics, observed Lara Brown, a political scientist at George Washington University in a Financial Times interview following the withdrawal of all women candidates except for Gabbard.Those who fought that campaign though while clearly frustrated, equally insist there is no point in looking back.Elizabeth Warren who for a time was seen as the candidate to beat in the Democratic field said on Thursday that she had ldquono regrets about her campaign.ldquoTen years I was teaching a few blocks from here and talking about what was broken in America and ideas about how to fix it, and pretty much nobody wanted to hear it, Warren said speaking in her home state of Massachusetts.But just like her rival candidates Warren still feels there is much fixing to be done when it comes to making sure women are on an equal political playing field as men.Many observers agree, including David Plouffe, the political strategist best known as the campaign manager for Barack Obamarsquos successful  presidential campaign.In an interview with Politico magazine Plouffe flagged up his belief that Warren ldquowas put through a ... crucible of the electability question in a slightly dferent way than some of the other candidates were.The presidency specically now seems to be a harder ceiling, says Plouffe who contends, ldquothere is more resistance to a woman president then there is to any male minority group, or a male of any sexual orientation.Democrat Mazie Hirono a senator from Hawaii echoes Plouffe views. She insists therersquos something about a woman running for a top executive post that brings out ldquostrange attitudes in American voters.ldquoThey think women are not tough enough, that we canrsquot do the job, Hirono insists, adding that it was something she experienced when running for governor in , though a Republican woman beat her in that race.Butone thing is beyond doubt itrsquos that Warren like the other women candidates in the recent campaign are more than up to the task.Known to stay at campaign rallies for hours after they finished Warren talks of what she calls a ldquopinky promise at her events, telling young women: ldquoIrsquom running for president because thatrsquos what girls do.Another woman candidate Senator Amy Klobuchar likewise described feeling a ldquokind of obligation to the girls who would approach her at events.ldquoThis is how I reconcile some of the fact that Irsquom not up there anymore. Itrsquos that you also see women with power, she said in an interview last week.ldquoThey ended up by not choosing the women, but that doesnrsquot mean the women are going to go away, Klobuchar added.Speaking after her withdrawal from the campaign on Thursday, Warren said thatldquoone of the hardest parts of this is all those pinky-promises and all those little girls who are going to have to wait four more years.There are those who will argue of course that Warren likely failed for reasons more than gender. She was after all competing with male counterpart Bernie Sanders for the progressive mantle while also arguing she could bridge the two wings of the Democratic Party better than her opponents.Askedsexism had played a role in her performance during the primary, Warren was equally candid, warning that she will have a lot more to say on the subject later. Her reluctance to spill the beans now is a measure of the potential damage she could do to the presidential hopes of her male Democrat colleagues still in the race.ldquoGender in this race, you know, that is the trap question for everyone, Warren told reporters for now.ldquoIf you say, lsquoYeah, there was sexism in this race,rsquo everyone says, lsquoWhiner.rsquo Andyou say, lsquoThere was no sexism,rsquo about a bazillion women think, lsquoWhat planet do you live on rsquoFor the second time in four years, an exceptionally qualied female candidate lost to her male counterparts, some objectively far less qualied. Warrenrsquos loss might not have been as rapid and headline grabbing as Hillary Clintonrsquos in , but the voters rejection still hurt deeply, so much so that she could only muster a third place in her home state of Massachusetts on Super Tuesday.Few doubt that those female candidates like her seemed held to a higher standard when it came to being ldquopresidential, electable and even likeable observed Swanee Hunt in a CNN op-ed article last week.For women those three characteristics ldquowar with one another, said the Hard University Kennedy School lecturer.ldquoA woman who seems nurturingpays a steep price. Gillibrand chose to take a soft approach by wearing dresses in contrast to the suitsthat many female candidates wear. Yet beyond optics, she took on issues more overtly women focused than those of her competitors, observed Hunt.Likewise in the case of Kamala Harris, was it her strong show of boldness in confronting Joe Biden on race that made her unlikable  asked Hunt.Harris after all wasnrsquot just simply a black candidate, given that Obama had already blazed that trail. ldquoShe was a black woman, Hunt opined.Biases about both gender and race likely intersected on a iety of fronts in the campaign. One example is that in a July poll of likely New Hampshire voters there were good favourability figures for both Warren and Harris.These came in at  per cent for Warren and  per cent for Harris, but were accompanied by poor ldquolikability ratings for them. Just  per cent of likely voters thought Warren was ldquolikable, and  per cent for Harris. Compared to that,  per cent of likely voters thought Biden and Sanders were likable.According to research from Tufts Universityrsquos Brian Schaffner and YouGovrsquos Sam Luks, released that same July, prejudices about women could well have translated to votersrsquo decision-making.The study found Democratic primary voters who scored higher on a ldquohostile sexism scale were less likely to choose either Warren or Harris as their top choice for the primary when polled.Many of those watching to see how far the United States had come between  and  in the degree to which gender presented a hurdle to women candidates will doubtless feel disappointed by such findings and the events of the past weeks during the Democratic campaign.Many too maintain that sexism pure and simple is one of the main reasons to blame for the disappearance of women candidates from the race for the presidency.ldquoIf Bernie Sanders were a woman, ldquoshe, as an angry, rumpled candidate, never would have made it beyond Mayor Sanders, and even that would have been a stretch, observed Jenner Burton a leading Democratic media consultant.ldquoLikewise,Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren or Amy Klobuchar were men, I have no doubt that one of them would be our nominee against Donald Trump, added Burton.But many still insist that what all this really boils down to is that candidates matter. While sexism continues to inhabit politics in America as it does in many places, one of the primary reasons say some is that the female candidates running for president did not make it to permanent frontrunner status is the spectre of Donald Trump and the  belief that many voters have that a woman cannot beat him.This and the Democratsrsquo obsession with finding the most ldquoelectable candidate to do just that, loomed over everything in the primary election watchers point out.Democratic voters they conclude ranked ldquothe ability to beat Trump as their main concern and decided that within the deeply ingrained and often invisible institutional norm, it means a woman canrsquot win.ldquoThere is perceived safety in whiteness and maleness, says Addisu Demissie, who ran Democrat Senator Cory Bookerrsquos campaign this year before he too pulled out.ldquoTherersquos a perceived risk in nominating women and people of colour that was just too great for the electorate this time. Itrsquos wrong and unfortunate and sad, but politics is about perception, Demissie told Politico magazine in a recent interview.Despite this latest setback for women candidates in the campaign, activists are quick to remind that it is only that, a setback.In the last four years, female candidates in the US political scene have made historic gains. Hillary Clinton became the first woman to win the presidential nomination for a major political party and a record number of women ran and were elected to office in Congress. These are the positive signs on which to build and good reasons for not becoming downhearted or disillusioned the same activists insist.ldquoSo today we mourn. We had six amazing women run, and now the top runners are two old white guys, observed Erin Vilardi founder and CEO of Vote Run Lead, a US national training programme for women to run for office.ldquoWe acknowledge that this is heartbreaking, and itrsquos OK to be sad. Tomorrow, though, wersquoll organise. Because shit never gets done without women.

title: nicola-sturgeon-coronavirus-cases-rise-rapidly-coming-days
story: The First Minister said she expected the NHS to come under "signicant pressure", but stressed the vast majority of people will experience only mild symptoms.It comes after it was reported officials are preparing for the death rate to reach , across the UK.Ms Sturgeon described such figures asaldquoworst case scenario and not forecasts.Speaking to the BBCs Politics Scotland, she said: "As of now, we have  confirmed cases [in Scotland]."I expect that to rise. I expect it to rise today, I expect to see it rise perhaps rapidly in the days to come."It is now very likely that we are facing a signicant outbreak of coronavirus across the UK and were preparing for that."Check the latest coronavirus updates as Scotland records positive cases of COVID-The First Minister said school closures are "one of several measures that could be considered here".She said there is still "lots we can do" to try to contain the spread of the virus.Ms Sturgeon added: "But when that ceases to be possible there are actions that we can take to try to slow down the spread of the virus and, crucially, reduce the number of people who are going to be affected at any one time, and thats crucial because obviously the fewer people affected at any one time the less the pressure will be on our NHS."That said, there is likely to be a signicant pressure on the NHS, so we are also planning to scale up the capacity the NHS has to treat people.:June Almeida, tribute to Scotlands forgotten hero of the coronavirus"The vast majority of people will not need hospital treatment. The vast majority of people who get this virus will have very mild symptoms ndash something akin to the cold or a mild case of flu."But for the smaller number who will need hospital treatment, the focus is on making sure the NHS is equipped to provide that care and treatment."

story: Two new cases of coronavirus have been confirmed in Scotland, bringing the total to three.One is in Grampian and the other in Ayrshire.Both patients were said to be clinically well and receiving care.One recently travelled to northern Italy and the other has had contact with a known positive case – this contact was not with the first positive case confirmed in Scotland in Tayside.Clinicians have begun contact tracing, the process of gathering details of the places they have visited and the people they have been in contact with.Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said: “Our first thoughts must be with the patients diagnosed with coronavirus, I wish them a full and speedy recovery.“We expect the number of cases to rise and Scotland is well-prepared for a signicant outbreak of coronavirus. “There is currently no treatment or vaccine so early detection measures will continue to be vital in helping to prevent the spread of the virus.“People have a vital role to play in helping us contain any outbreak by following the latest health and travel advice, and following basic hygiene precautions, such as washing hands frequently, not touching their face and covering their nose and mouth with a tissue when coughing or sneezing.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.kincardineshireobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  Aberdeenshire licensing boards could merge viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "KINC | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "KINC | Article Teaser"
